data.title: Add option for decoupling Draw() from Update()
data.body:
See the forum topic I created here: http://community.monogame.net/t/calling-draw-more-frequently-than-update/8328

I think it can be useful for many games if the Draw() method can be called more than once per Update(). Think of games that don't depend on fast user input like slower strategy or puzzle games. You might want to update the game logic only, say, 30 times a second, while still synchronizing the draw calls to the display's refresh rate of 60 or 120 Hz. During the remaining draw calls, you could interpolate animations or physics to provide players using a display with a refresh rate higher than the frequency of the core game loop with a smoother visual appearance.

Currently, it seems like Draw() will only ever be called at maximum once for every Update(). I would like to be able to decouple Draw() from Update(), so that the framework tries to call Draw()
- as often as possible when vsync is off or
- as often as the display allows when vsync is on, ideally matching its refresh rate.

This could be implemented via some additional property in the Game class in order to keep compatibility with XNA and the current defaults.

data.title: Move some stuff to NuGet
data.body:
So... here we go:
- It would be much better to not add local assemblies during the install and instead make the default templates reliant on NuGet
  - a problem that will occur for anyone transitioning from 3.5 to 3.6 is that they need to recreate the project to get the SDL native libs
  - we could package all the native libs inside the NuGet and instead of adding them to the project we could create a .targets file that automatically copy them to the output folder, therefore the end users won't even notice any difference between future versions
- we could also create a Universal MGCB.exe assembly in each package or a separate package
  - for the most part we just need to replace few "#ifs" with runtime detection
  - targets file should be in this NuGet package
  - this would make it so the end user doesn't even need to install anything besides a NuGet package or 2 to get started
- we could also package Pipeline Tool, but I would rather leave it as a system install
  - we should however make it check the current .mgcb files project for a NuGets MGCB.exe to use instead of the system one

In short:
- Make MGCB universal
- Package MGCB inside NuGet packages, or create a separate one for it?
- Package native libs inside each platforms NuGet package
- Make templates reliant on NuGet stuff
- Remove local assemblies and .targets file from the installers

data.title: EffectPass loses textures when applying shader samplers
data.body:
In the method `SetShaderSamplers` in `MonoGame.Framework/Graphics/Effect/EffectPass.cs`, device textures are overridden by sampler `param.Data` unconditionally.

I have an XNA game that assumes device textures are preserved after applying effects. Adding a null check before overriding the device textures fixes my rendering issues.

```
                if (texture != null)
                    textures[sampler.textureSlot] = texture;
```

Disclaimer: I don't know if this is the correct fix nor I can test this on Windows/XNA myself as I'm porting bling on Linux/DesktopGL.

We should upgrade our current version of NUnit from 2.x to 3.x.  This would involve:

- Make sure running unit tests via Resharper's runner still works.

This came up as part of a discussion on supporting VS2015 (see https://github.com/MonoGame/MonoGame/issues/5254).

data.title: Why don't MonoGame.Tests.Windows work with VS2015 test manager?
data.body:
Why don't the unit tests for MonoGame.Tests.Windows work in the VS2015 test manager? Currently, it seems that you have to run a separate MonoGameTests executable found in the output folder of MonoGame.Tests.Windows. Output goes to an HTML page.

Visual Studio has pretty nice test integration and reporting features. It's also very nice to be able to set breakpoints in your unit tests right in VS, and step through code. VS tests are compatible with nunit, but the tests won't compile if you reference the Nuget version of nunit (http://community.monogame.org/t/monogame-tests-windows-not-compiling-in-vs2015-solved/8320)

Is there a historic reason why the test framework isn't compatible with VS? Do people not like the VS test manager? 

I realize that Monogame is a cross platform project, but since the solutions themselves are Visual Studio solutions, it seems logical that the test framework with be compatible with Visual Studio too.

data.title: BoundingBox.Contains(Vector3) returns incorrect ContainmentType
data.body:
The code of BoundingBox.Contains(Vector3) method checks if any of the points is on the edge of the bounding box and immediately returns `ContainmentType.Interjects` even if the given Vector3 is completely inside it.

The method should return `ContainmentType.Contains` if all of the points are inside and `ContainmentType.Interjects` if any of them are inside.

data.title: Vector2 behavior in SpriteBatch.DrawString()
data.body:
So in one of my attempts to center some text over a texture I encountered the following `Vector2` behavior:

``` cs
spriteBatch.DrawString(......., new Vector2(texturePosition.X + (texture.Width - font.MeasureString("Test").X) / 2, texturePosition.Y + (texture.Height - font.MeasureString("Test").Y) / 2), ....);
```

This looks all good but as I said above, I didn't expect that exact behavior from the vector... So I didn't cast the X coordinate of the vector to `int` and the math inside was producing a decimal number (e.g. `250.5f`). This made the following difference in the text:
![diff](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13241568/19644044/539a8a14-99f6-11e6-90f5-fa57349c18aa.png)
Top image = decimal X
Bottom image = integer X
Notice the blurry letters in the top image like `y`, `c`, `e`, etc.

I've actually been wondering for a few days what caused my text there to look blurry, while all other text looked fine. Then I casted the whole thing to `int` and it got fixed. I'm not sure if the behavior is the same with `SpriteBatch.Draw()` for textures too...

Feature request:
Can we have a `Point` overload on the `Draw()`/`DrawString()` method for positioning? Only reason being that it accepts `int` and `int` only. That way, I'd be sure that whatever logic I put in the position code won't blur the text/image. This can be useful for static (idle) images/text. If one wants to make smooth image/text movement, they should use `Vector2` for position instead.

data.title: Add Flush method to the SpriteBatch
data.body:
Right now, if one wants to send the SpriteBatch's draw data to the graphics device and continue to draw (i.e. if he changed the ScissorRectangle), then he needs to call the End method followed by Begin. That could be a performance hit(and actually it is according to my testing) as every End/Begin reapplies the same graphics states over and over again.
An explicit Flush method would solve that issue.
